author: @LamarFrancis
text:
Great video as always. Tangentially, i think something that can also be taken from this whole situation (besides the obvious & the things said in the video) is that if you want people to truly understand you (or to even persuade them), you have to make them feel like they‚Äôre being listened to.

It‚Äôs not the main point, but it‚Äôs a point that I see so often. People dismissing people‚Äôs experiences, genuine gripes (not the ones manufactured by *insert ism*) often lead them not to listen. 

And we can always say that they should listen to the truth, but if we want them to receive it, we have to make them feel heard. 

Idk why i felt the need to say that, but i did lol.

author: @berryzem
text:
I think the problem (I think Olay kind of touched on this at one point) with instances like this is that any more it's outrage that sells. It's the outrage of the lie that gets people riled up and talking about it. It's why black women who tell the truth about their assault don't get nearly the empathy and support they desperately need and deserve compared to the outrage and vitriol women like Rho receive and will continue to receive for years to come. 

It is wrong that Rho lied about the details. But, more importantly, why is it that instead of using that energy to go and support the black women who tell the truth, these black men take to Twitter to celebrate their "got ya" moment and spew their disdain over cases like this? I think Foreign made a really good point at the end (Olay has mentioned this multiple times, too) that it's the institutions that are the problem. It's the pd. It's misogynoir. This is, at best, myopic and a symptom of the problem. Trying to fix this by trying to send her to jail or prison is just going to make things worse.

replies.author: @handle-Generic
replies.text:
Well there's a distinction to be made, is it all instances of violence against black women or just cases where the truth is questionable?

Bc what I've seen online is when it's clear that the male is an abuser there's no question from black men as to who's wrong (ray Rice etc). 

One thing that I've seen pretty consistently is when there is mutual violence (that doesn't turn lopsided against the woman) is the crowd or viewer acknowledge "she started it" or "escalated it" bc in that instance they're witnessing  violence that hasn't risen yet to abuse.

But generally when it's clear that that man is the abuser it's very rare that I've seen bystanders do nothing let alone  celebrate it.

replies.author: @jinx526
replies.text: ‚Äã@handle-Generic So you didn't notice what happened to Megan thee stallion? There are plenty of cases of where the nature and details of the abuse is clear yet the female victim is met with suspicion, hostility or blamed for their suffering. There is an irrational and unfair expectation for victims to be perfect. Male victims included. Life is messy, violent and/or abusive situations are extremely messy. It's ridiculous to expect any involved to be angels or innocent damsels in distress. It's just not reality and doesn't help build the consciousness necessary to help people recover and prevent these incidents. I think some people are more interested performance of morality ( condemning lying)  rather than being empathetic and pragmatic with situations. Victims can and probably will lie because they think it will protect them or increase their chances of getting help. That says more about the public than it does the victim. We pick and choose who's deserving of salvation and fail to analyze the full context of why some may lie in these scenarios. We pick apart the humanity of alleged victims and even the alleged abusers before proper investigation and reflection.  We fail to acknowledge how our biases feed into these scenarios and also perpetuate the cycle of the abuse. The onus is not just on the victim to be honest but the entire public. We do live in society that likes to protect and justify abuse. We live in a victim shaming culture. If we can't be honest and address that how can we expect victims to take the risk with honesty?

replies.author: @berryzem
replies.text: @handle-Generic Just wanted to clarify I meant celebrate that "got ya" moment (went back and edited my first comment) when people on Twitter who were convinced it must have been made up because their default response to the situation is "not" to believe the woman. I'm not saying people witnessing the abuse happening are literally celebrating it. That's something else entirely.

author: @jerzeenative
text:
My issue with this whole situation is: if she did incite this situation as the aggressor and fabricate this situation in a deceitful manner the way it was framed, she used incendiary topics (violence against black women and lack of protection) as springboards to create the very polarizing discussions that are and have been happening. That is foul, and she is an agent of yt supremacy. 

False accusations are also a part of the AA male experience, usually resultant of yt women tears. To have one of our own resort to the same tactics of yt supremacy is the rub. She essentially weaponized victimnood and purposefully added to the discourse of several societal ails in our communities. This would be using our women's experience (pain) as a prop while simultaneously denigrating our man.

She also took advantage of our empathy. I, for one, road with her because all victims should be believed until facts presented show otherwise.

replies.author: @jerzeenative

@josephsmiley1¬† thinking they are lying without evidence is not only a lack of empathy, but also sociopathy. Humans are social creatures. Just like the one lady stated, if everyone went around immediately doubting everyone and everything, absolutely nothing would get done.

With that said, my believing her takes how much money out of my pockets? My believing her adversely affects me in what manner? Both are rhetorical questions. Maybe you have some scale you use to grade belief. Let me explain this belief of mine: face value. No different from if you told me you were a lawyer, I wouldn't disbelieve you. I would take you at face value and keep it pushing. I don't know about you, but I would rather err to the side of humanity and dignity for a victim.

This view is not so mypopic that another value cannot exist simultaneously. That value is of due process for the accused. 1. the victim should be able to come forward without fear and be provided support 2. the accused should not be guilty until they have received due process.

I will continue giving grace and the benefit of doubt until I am provided with facts contradictory to the person's story. That grace is extended to all parties involved. That is balance.

author: @RethabileLetshae
text:
I just want to fist start by saying that this has been a very insightful conversation I had witnessed. It gave me a perspective on how to view most of the dynamics of black women and non-masculine presenting black people in society. Initially, I was outraged when I first heard of the story, and my thoughts were that it's very disheartening to see black women, ESPECIALLY dark skinned black women, not being protected by black men in society. Now, before people come for me - it's not all men obviously, but it seemed to be the general conversation amongst men in this panel, and I found it important to mention that because they had a substantial platform and subsequent interest. I watched a video similar to this, and it had both black women and black men discussing the topic of black women and social protection. Most of the men in that video mentioned that they TOO were afraid of the guy who stroke back at the time (of course considering the fact that they didn't have the full story), and stressed that they would be putting their lives on the line because they want to play the hero.

At the time, I was studying Colorism and it's historical trauma - especially pertaining black women. From watching F.D Signifier, Lil' Bill and Foreign Man In A Foreign Land videos about Black Masculinity. They inspired me to search further and study the history of the oppression of black women by both the black and white community. It hurt me to find that even STATS confirm that black women receive generally less social protection in society than any other women in society (the homicide rates and birth mortality rates being the first reference of point.). Now, getting to my point... As I sit here and watch this video as a non-masculine presenting individual, I am hurt by what the two of the three men on your panel are saying by ignoring the fact that whether this lady lied or not; a woman reporting a case like this is normally questioned EVEN if it was true. They are refusing to acknowledge the fact that even if the woman was fighting ANOTHER woman, the responder STILL had an advantage over the attacker. One man even casually spoke about how she may have deserved something like this by attacking people first, as if that justifies the fact that being stricken with a blunt object that could potentially be a WEAPON as a response is okay. Even if the man was smaller or had less strength than her, he STILL had an advantage over her simply because he had a WEAPON as a response to violence when he could have resorted to SO many other non-violent solutions. One of the men also emphasized that although this happened and we'll say... This was true (hypothetically speaking), there was still a group of men who would question on whether or not she was attacked. SAME thing with Megan before the police proved her right. It shows that black women are not believed most of the time, and that until they have proof then something will be done. Now here's the sweet part; one of the two men was so adamant that something should be done about people who lie in these instances, like there wasn't a sea of black men bashing her and calling her names (I'm just being sarcastic of course). I agree, if they press charges and are found to being lying then they should be countersued by the state for perjury and malicious intent. That can be something that is discussed,  and also whether or not the person they lied about wants to press charges or not. But STILL; this was not the point of this conversation- or I'm assuming. 

These 2 men proved to me that psychologically, black men have little to no understanding of the empathy that black women and non-masc black people are seeking from masc-presenting black men, and that they seek not to understand most of the time but DEFEND black men without critically assessing the key element of the situation. There was one woman on the panel as well who gave empathy to this level of thinking from black men. And listen; I am NOT saying that there aren't beautiful, masculine-presenting, healthy, good black men out there... I am saying that there aren't enough of those out there reprimanding the men to actually understanding what black women mean. Men like Jason Wilson, a BLACK man, who I cry every time I watch his videos. He brings a very vulnerable yet strong, open-minded and symbiotic way of viewing the world without losing your identity as a black boy/man. I just wish he had more of a platform like these RED PILL BLACK MEN you normally see on the internet because he would buffer most of these toxic ideologies that they spread. Now, I want my black man to eat - but masculinity is providing, which means you provide insight and awareness on matters that affect the future generation. It could also help prevent the unwanted experiences of most of black boys' childhoods. 

Now, there's nothing wrong with this woman seeking a GoFundMe to get financial assistance with her medical fees. Also, she DIDN'T press any charges pertaining the incident. But I will say, that mutual combat is always reliant on the intrinsic scenario in which the case is labeled under. I'm sure we can all agree that being the only one in combat with a weapon is advantageously unfair. Yes, she LIED about what happened. At the same, we still don't know the context of the conversation that was had before she struck the guy, as she had claimed that he wanted her number. I am STILL not justifying her actions and her LIES, but I will not DISREGARD the fact that THIS happens to women who don't give out their numbers if not worse. As for the woman going into the community and apologizing, I don't see why she should because she didn't get social protection; EVEN after the truth came out. And lastly, I think the new topic we should be talking about is how do we reprimand and rehabilitate people that makes mistakes instead of treating them like uncivilized individuals. I think it's important to acknowledge that the main reason for crime is poverty, and until we talk about how that's trauma for a lot of people - we're not ready to have all this conversation. With all that being said; I don't see why they need to persecute them.

In the past few years I've been trying to make sure not to lump ppl of color into one group, like "the black voter" but it seems like something is trying to break up black unity. Again I'm an outsider looking in and just trying to understand this country we live in. I will say I grew up in the south around a lot of prejudice and I've always known that when white ppl realize they are losing power/dominance they were going to freak out. I hope that I'm wrong because it would be a major set back for everyone.
